column1: '''Beornings''' were a people of the upper [[Vales of Anduin]], between [[Mirkwood]] and the [[Misty Mountains]].<ref name=AppMen/><ref name=H18/><ref name =FRII1/>
As other [[Northmen]], the Beornings descended from Men of the [[First Age]] who were related to the [[Edain]],<ref>{{App
column2: Men}}</ref> perhaps akin to the [[House of Hador
column4: 8}}</ref> As such, the Beornings were close kin of the [[Éothéod]], the [[Woodmen]] of [[Mirkwood]] and the [[Bardings]].<ref>{{App

column1: After the [[Battle of Five Armies]] and the decimation of the [[Orcs of the Misty Mountains]], many Northmen gathered around [[Beorn]] who became a great chief. It is possible that the Beornings became known as a people through being descendants of Beorn.<ref name=H18>{{H

The Beornings kept open the passages of the [[Ford of Carrock]] and the [[High Pass]] in return for tolls,<ref name=FRII1/> likely clearing the paths from [[Dale]] to [[Rivendell]] from evil creatures such as [[Orcs]] and [[Wargs]].<ref>{{TI
In the events leading up to the [[War of the Ring]], the Beornings helped [[Aragorn]], who was taking [[Gollum]] to Mirkwood, to cross the [[Anduin]].<ref>{{UT
During the War, [[Grimbeorn]], son of Beorn, was the leader of the Beornings.<ref name=FRII1/> It is possible that [[Sauron]]'s forces had attacked them in early {{TA
column2: 3019}}: when [[Frodo Baggins]] wore  [[the One Ring]] upon [[Amon Hen]], he saw the land of the Beornings aflame.<ref>{{FR

column1: After the War, the Beornings and the Woodmen were given central [[Eryn Lasgalen]] by [[Thranduil]] and [[Celeborn]].<ref>{{App

column2: Common Speech]],<ref>[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], "[[Letter to Leila Keene and Pat Kirke]]" (cf. ''[[The Peoples of Middle-earth]]'', p. 72)</ref> and had perhaps also their own dialect of it or tongue.<ref name=AppMen>{{App

column1: Through many generations, the descendants of Beorn were like him [[skin-changers]], able to take the shape of a [[bears
column2: bear]].<ref group=note>Since it is unknown if all Beornings came from the line of Beorn, one can only guess if this was valid for all the Beornings.</ref> Some of Beorn's descendants were grim like him and even "bad", but none of them matched Beorn in size and strength.<ref name=H18/>

column1: The Beornings seemed to have shared a dislike for [[Dwarves]],<ref name=FRII1/><ref>{{H
column2: 7}}: [Beorn speaking:] "''I am not over fond of dwarves''"</ref> perhaps related to the latters' praise of metals and the formers' disinterest in it.<ref>{{H
column3: 7}}: "''[The Dwarves] spoke most of gold and silver and jewels and the making of things by smith-craft, and Beorn did not appear to care for such things: there were no things of gold or silver in his hall, and few save the knives were made of metal at all.</ref>

column1: They were known as great bakers, famous for their honey-cakes (which could feed travellers similarly to the ''[[lembas]]'') although they were reluctant to share them with travelers around the time of the War of the Ring.<ref>{{FR
